awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Production Pathways of Biopolymers for Barrier Paper Coatings
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop new sustainable packaging materials.   An important class of materials is polyhydroxyalkonoates (PHA).  Production of PHA from carbon sources has generally been associated with high costs, precluding widespread adoption. Natural gas and biogas are cost-effective alternatives, however, and established PHA-producing microbes use only about half the carbon from methane, releasing the rest as carbon dioxide. This project will develop protocols to use newly discovered microbes for efficient PHA production. The newly discovered microbial platform would enable efficient utilization of biogas with high carbon conversion, allowing high efficiency and (near) zero emission PHA production. The produced PHA will be formulated into barrier paper coatings for food service packaging that is recyclable, compostable, and marine-biodegradable. 

The proposed project will validate and develop the biological pathways for high-yield conversion of biogas using newly discovered microbes. Current PHA production remains noncompetitive to fossil-based polymers due to relatively high raw materials cost and low polymer yield with established microbial platforms, utilizing only a portion of the carbon from methane and emitting the rest as carbon dioxide. Breakthroughs in PHA production cost require high-efficiency carbon conversion. The microbes of interest have demonstrated improved carbon conversion, high polymer yield, and the promise for a (near) zero emission production. The goals of the project are to elucidate and optimize the cultivation parameters of the newly discovered cultures and build novel PHA copolymer pathways in the organisms by constructing synthetic biology framework(s).  The project will also develop fermentation protocols that optimize yield for producing commercial PHA copolymers for further scaling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The global economy is consuming upwards of 400 million tons of fossil-based plastics a year with at least half of it in the form of single-use items. Even though single-use plastics are typically used for only 15 minutes, they are disposed into landfills or oceans at alarming rates, where they degrade over centuries. Fossil-based plastics are not degraded by known biology at any reasonable scale, but rather by UV light and physical forces until they become infinitesimal particles. These micro- and nano- plastics are accumulating on Earth at unimaginable scale. Scientists report microplastics on every continent, in the oceans, in the food, in wild and domestic animals, and of course in human bodies. The consequences of microplastic ingestion on animals and humans will undoubtedly lead to enhanced vigilance in recycling programs, which stand at around 5% in the US and less than 9% globally.  Despite anticipated improvement in recycling, there will always be more used and thrown away than reused. Drastic steps are needed today to first reduce plastic use, and second to find replacement chemistries which offer functionality, but also product circularity.

Through this lens Phaxtec has used synthetic biology to engineer bacteria which can metabolize methane and carbon dioxide, two potent greenhouse gases and components of biogas, to make a naturally occuring and useful material called Polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHA). PHA biopolyesters are produced and degraded by all living organisms, and they are at the forefront of sustainable plastics replacement. PHA are marine, freshwater and soil biodegradable; and exhibit versatility in many application areas including durable consumer goods and temporary single-use plastics and packaging. With a diverse array of molecular structures, PHA biopolymers promise eco-friendly solutions across industries, ranging from packaging to personal care to medicine, allowing humanity to make a pivotal stride toward a more sustainable and adaptable future.

Research at Phaxtec funded by the NSF SBIR Phase 1 grant award has resulted in intellectual property in the production of PHA directly from biogas. Phaxtec anticipates filing additional IP from the work undertaken under this grant award, however, this information is proprietary.

In conclusion, this project represents one of the first times that biogas will be used commercially as a feedstock for genetically engineered bacteria to produce market attractive PHA polymers.

This project will increase widespread production of a low-cost biodegradable plastics replacement from biogas and with gentle prodding from government agencies eventually displace a substantial number of fossil-based plastics from landfills and oceans. PHA biopolymers have the potential to capture an increasing fraction of the single-use foodservice plastics market, thereby giving consumers the choice to purchase affordable, environmentally friendly, biodegradable product packaging.
